title: Effects of diet on cranial morphology and biting ability in musteloid mammals
abstract: Size and shape are often considered important variables that lead to variation in performance. In studies of feeding, size-corrected metrics of the skull are often used as proxies of biting performance; however, few studies have examined the relationship between cranial shape in its entirety and estimated bite force across species and how dietary ecologies may affect these variables differently. Here, we used geometric morphometric and phylogenetic comparative approaches to examine relationships between cranial morphology and estimated bite force in the carnivoran clade Musteloidea. We found a strong relationship between cranial size and estimated bite force but did not find a significant relationship between cranial shape and sizecorrected estimated bite force. Many-to-one mapping of form to function may explain this pattern because a variety of evolutionary shape changes rather than a single shape change may have contributed to an increase in relative biting ability. We also found that dietary ecologies influenced cranial shape evolution but did not influence cranial size nor size-corrected bite force evolution. Although musteloids with different diets exhibit variation in cranial shapes, they have similar estimated bite forces suggesting that other feeding performance metrics and potentially nonfeeding traits are also important contributors to cranial evolution. We postulate that axial and appendicular adaptations and the interesting feeding behaviours reported for species within this group also facilitate different dietary ecologies between species. Future work integrating cranial, axial and appendicular form and function with behavioural observations will reveal further insights into the evolution of dietary ecologies and other ecological variables.

abstract.text: Size and shape are often considered important variables that lead to variation in performance. body_text.text: The strength of the form-function relationship has provided biologists with insight into species' abilities to carry out ecological tasks, especially when behavioural observations are scarce. These measured or estimated performances are important because they provide links between morphology, ecology and overall fitness (Arnold, 1983; Wainwright, 1994) . Because feeding is paramount to fitness, researchers have investigated the morphology and anatomy of the skull and its influence on prey capture performances such as suction feeding (Westneat, 2005; Wainwright et al., 2007; Holzman et al., 2008) , lingual feeding (Schwenk & Throckmorton, 1989; Wake & Deban, 2000) and biting ability (Herrel et al., 2005; Mehta & Wainwright, 2007; Santana et al., 2010) . In turn, these morphometric and functional studies elucidate the many ways in which vertebrate species overcome acquiring and processing elusive or other types of challenging prey (reviewed in Schwenk, 2000) .

Across many disparate vertebrate clades, the ability to generate relatively high bite forces is an important performance trait that affords animals the ability to consume otherwise unobtainable resources (Herrel et al., 2007; Anderson et al., 2008; Bult e et al., 2008; Santana et al., 2010; Gignac & Erickson, 2016) . Because stronger biting ability facilitates increased foraging efficiency and net energy intake (Herrel et al., 2001; Verwaijen et al., 2002; van der Meij & Bout, 2006; Anderson et al., 2008) , selection is expected to shape biting performance to satisfy dietary demands (Verwaijen et al., 2002; Herrel et al., 2005; Mori & Vincent, 2008; Nogueira et al., 2009; Santana et al., 2012; Maestri et al., 2016) . These studies further reveal that species integrating harder (e.g. hard fruit, nuts, bones, shelled invertebrates) and/or larger food items into their diets exhibit higher bite forces compared to closely related species that do not consume hard and/or relatively larger prey (Verwaijen et al., 2002; Herrel et al., 2005; Mori & Vincent, 2008; Nogueira et al., 2009; Santana et al., 2012; Maestri et al., 2016) . Evolution towards a larger head and body is the simplest way to increase the size and effectiveness of functional performances (Marroig & Cheverud, 2005) . Unsurprisingly, members of many vertebrate clades exhibit strong positive relationships between cranial size and bite forces (van der Meij & Bout, 2004; Christiansen & Wroe, 2007; Erickson et al., 2013; Maestri et al., 2016; Santana & Miller, 2016) . Niche-dependent constraints, however, often limit the evolution towards larger body sizes (see Zelditch et al., 2017) . Therefore, evolutionary shifts towards relatively higher bite forces can also occur through modification of skull shape such as increasing the size of attachment sites of the jaw adductor muscles and/or enhancing mechanical advantage of jaw closure by lengthening the input levers of the jaw adductors and/or shortening the jaw length (Radinsky, 1981; Santana et al., 2012; Collar et al., 2014; Zelditch et al., 2017) . Many researchers have identified significant shape differences between species with different dietary ecologies (Dumont et al., 2015; Zelditch et al., 2017; McLean et al., 2018) , but few have examined whether these shape differences also translate to bite force differences. Although some clades exhibit strong correlations between size-corrected bite force and cranial shapes (Herrel et al., 2005; Nogueira et al., 2009; Dollion et al., 2016) , the vast majority of vertebrate clades exhibit many-to-one mapping of form to function where distinct cranial morphologies lead to the same feeding performance (Alfaro et al., 2005; Wainwright et al., 2005; Young et al., 2007; Collar et al., 2014; Kolmann et al., 2015; Zelditch et al., 2017) . To increase bite force, species can increase the size of jaw adductor muscle attachment sites through a variety of cranial changes including increases in zygomatic breadth, sagittal crest height, mastoid breadth and braincase surface area (Radinsky, 1981) , highlighting how multiple morphological changes can lead to the same performance outcome. Therefore, whether cranial shape and bite force in other vertebrate clades exhibits a one-to-one or many-to-one relationship requires additional examination.

In this study, we use the superfamily Musteloidea to examine the relationship between cranial morphology and bite force as well as investigate how form and function are affected by dietary ecology. With 85 putative species in 33 genera, Musteloidea is an ecomorphologically diverse clade of carnivoran mammals (Kitchener et al., 2018) . Musteloids exhibit diverse diets ranging from the generalist diets of raccoons, skunks and badgers to the specialized diets of the herbivorous red panda, hypercarnivorous weasels and piscivorous otters (Macdonald et al., 2018) . Much research has examined the craniomandibular morphologies and musculature that facilitate these disparate dietary ecologies within musteloid clades (e.g. Riley, 1985; Friscia et al., 2007; Figueirido et al., 2014; Law et al., 2016; Davis & Williams, 2018) . In a comparative study of 31 musteloid species, Dumont et al. (2015) found that cranial shapes significantly differed between dietary ecologies. However, whether these differences in cranial shape translate to functional differences such as estimated bite force between dietary groups remains unknown. Therefore, we used geometric morphometric approaches and a phylogenetic comparative framework to examine relationships between cranial shape, estimated bite force and dietary ecology in musteloids. We first tested the relationship between cranial shape and cranial size across musteloids to determine the effects of evolutionary allometry on musteloid crania. We then examined scaling relationships between cranial size and estimated bite force as well as correlations between shape differences in the cranium and size-corrected estimated bite forces. Lastly, we tested the hypothesis that dietary ecology influenced the evolution of cranial size, cranial shape and estimated bite force.

We 3D scanned 450 female crania specimens across 67 musteloid species (median = 7 per species) using a Next Engine 3D Ultra HD surface scanner (see Table S1 for list of specimens and museums). All specimens were fully mature, determined by the closure of exoccipital-basioccipital and basisphenoid-basioccipital sutures on the cranium. Because musteloids exhibit significant sexual dimorphism in the crania , we analysed only females to eliminate the effects of sex on cranial morphological, which would influence performance. We quantified cranial shape using 3D geometric morphometrics (Rohlf & Slice, 1990; Zelditch et al., 2012) with 52 landmarks and 85 semi-landmarks ( Fig. 1 ; Table S2 ). Landmarks were digitized using Checkpoint (Stratovan Corporation, Davis, CA, USA) and superimposed by Generalized Procrustes analysis (Rohlf & Slice, 1990 ). Semi-landmarks on the curves were allowed to slide along their tangent vectors until their positions minimized bending energy (Bookstein, 1997; Zelditch et al., 2012) . As part of the superimposition procedure, bilaterally homologous landmarks and semi-landmarks on the cranium were reflected across the median plane and averaged using the geomorph function bilat.symmetry. All Procrustes superimposition was performed in the R package geomorph 3.0.6 (Adams & Ot arola-Castillo, 2013). We then quantified cranial size of each specimen by calculating the geometric mean of the condylobasal length (distance from the anteriormost point on the premaxillae to the plane of the posterior surface of the occipital condyles) and cranial width (greatest distance across the zygomatic arches). Geometric mean for the combination of skull length and width and centroid size exhibited a strong positive relationship (R 2 = 0.99; P < 0.001).

We quantified carnassial bite forces using Thomason's (1991) dry skull method, a bite force estimation based solely on osteological specimens. Thomason (1991) originally estimated bite forces in opossums (Didelphis virginiana) and found them to be comparable to in vivo bite forces taken from live individuals (see Discussion). We estimated cross-sectional areas (CSA) of the temporalis and masseter-pterygoid complex by outlining the left and right infratemporal fossae from photographs of the posterodorsal and ventral views of the crania, respectively (Fig. S1 ). The resulting areas were then multiplied by a muscle stress value 30 N cm À2 to estimate forces of the temporalis and masseter-pterygoid complex and modelled as a single force vector (T and M). Each force vector was assumed to act through their centroids perpendicular to the plane of the muscle CSA. We then measured the moment arms [the distance from centroid to the temporomandibular joint (TMJ)] of the temporalis (MAT) using the lateral view of the cranium and masseterpterygoid complex (MAM) using the ventral view of the cranium. We also measured the out-lever (O M ) as the distance from the carnassial tooth to the TMJ joint ( Fig. S1 ). We estimated bite force by dividing the total moment by the out-lever and multiplied it by 2 to account for bilateral biting:
BF ¼ 2 T Ã MAT þ M Ã MAM O M
All cross-sectional areas and linear measurements were taken digitally using ImageJ v. 1.48 (Schneider et al., 2012) .

We classified the 67 species into one of five dietary categories, an extension of Van Valkenburgh's (2007) three dietary classification scheme to incorporate the aquatic and arboreal lifestyles observed in musteloids: hypercarnivory with diets consisting of > 70% terrestrial vertebrates, mesocarnivory with diets consisting of > 50% terrestrial vertebrates, hypocarnivory with diets consisting of > 70% nonplant and nonvertebrates (e.g. insects, earthworms), aquatic carnivory with diets consisting of > 90% aquatic prey (e.g. bottom-dwelling fish, crustaceans, molluscs) and herbivory with diets consisting of > 90% plant material. Dietary data were obtained primarily from Mammalian Species accounts (see Table S3 for references).

We performed all statistical analyses under a phylogenetic framework in the R environment (R Core Team, 2017) using the most recent musteloid phylogeny . The phylogeny was time-calibrated (units million of years) using 74 fossils under the fossilized birth-death model . We calculated species means of natural log-transformed (ln) cranial size, cranial shape (Procrustes coordinates) and ln-estimated bite force prior to analyses.

We first tested for evolutionary allometry on cranial shape against cranial size by performing a phylogenetic Procrustes regression (Adams, 2014a) and calculating the regression score (10 000 iterations; Mitteroecker et al., 2004) with the geomorph function procD.pgls. Because there was significant allometry (see Results), we used allometry-free shape in all subsequent analyses by computing the shape residuals extracted from Procrustes ANOVA (Goodall, 1991) of cranial shape against cranial size. We then examined the relationship between cranial size and estimated bite force using phylogenetic generalized least squares (PGLS) regression with the R package caper (Orme, 2013) . All regression parameters were simultaneously estimated with phylogenetic signal in the residual error as Pagel's (1999) lambda (Revell, 2010) . Lastly, we examined the relationship between allometry-free cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force using a phylogenetic two-block partial least squares (pPLS) analysis (Adams & Felice, 2014) with the geomorph function phylo. integration. Size-corrected estimated bite forces were obtained as residuals extracted from PGLS regressions of estimated bite force against cranial size from above.
body_text.section: Relationships between cranial size, cranial shape and estimated bite force

body_text.text: We tested the hypothesis that dietary ecology influences the evolution of cranial size, allometry-free Landmarks (black circles and triangles) and semi-landmarks (white circles and triangles) used for geometric morphometric analysis of skull shape and size. Circles denote the landmarks and semi-landmarks of the rostral module, and triangles denote the landmarks and semi-landmarks of the braincase module. Description of landmarks is found in Table S2 . cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force using generalized evolutionary modelling (Hansen, 1997; Butler & King, 2004; Beaulieu et al., 2012) . We first generated 5000 stochastically mapped trees of the five dietary ecologies with the make.simmap function (Bollback, 2006) in phytools (Revell, 2011) . We then fit four evolutionary models onto each cranial trait: (i) a single-rate Brownian (BM1) model that assumes trait variance accumulates proportionally to evolutionary time under a random walk (Felsenstein, 1985) , (ii) a multi-rate Brownian (BMM) model that allows rates to differ between dietary regimes, (iii) a singleoptimum Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) model that constrains each trait to evolve towards one optimum, and (iv) a multi-optima OU (OUM) model that allows each dietary regime to exhibit a different trait optimum. Support for the OUM model would suggest that diet influences the evolution of cranial size, allometry-free cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force. We fit these four models onto the cranial size and size-corrected estimated bite force data using the R package OUwie (Beaulieu et al., 2012) . We accounted for measurement error (standard error) for each model fitting by adding the variance of the means to the diagonal elements (variances) of the model-specific variance-covariance matrix. We used pooled sample variance for samples with only one specimen. For allometry-free cranial shape, we reduced the number of variables by conducting a principal components analysis of the allometry-free Procrustes shape and used the first four PC axes (cumulatively explained 75% of total shape variation) as our new shape variables. Because using PCs as univariate variables is potentially problematic, we fitted multivariate models onto these new PC shape variables using the R package mvMORPH (Clavel et al., 2015) . We fit all models across 5000 stochastically mapped trees to take into account uncertainty in the ancestral character states.
body_text.section: Influence of dietary ecology on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: We also tested whether dietary habits resulted in differences in cranial size and size-corrected estimated bite forces using phylogenetic ANOVAs (10 000 iterations) and used post hoc tests to compare the means among dietary groups with the phytools function phy-lANOVA (Revell, 2011) . We tested for differences in allometry-free cranial shape between dietary groups using a Procrustes ANOVA (10 000 iterations) with the geomorph function procD.pgls. We then measured the Procrustes distances of allometry-free cranial shape between the dietary groups by performing pairwise permutation tests with the Morpho function permudist (Schlager, 2016) . Lastly, we determined how well dietary ecologies can distinguish between cranial shapes in morphospace by performing a canonical variate analysis (CVA) with a jackknife crossvalidation procedure using the CVA Morpho function (Schlager, 2016) .
body_text.section: Influence of dietary ecology on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: Relationships between cranial size, cranial shape and estimated bite force

We found significant allometry of cranial shape on cranial size (SS = 0.003, MS = 0.003, R 2 = 0.09, P < 0.001). As cranial size increased across musteloids, we observed relative broadening of the zygomatic arches and vaulting of the braincase (Fig. 2) . We also found a strong positive relationship between cranial size and estimated bite force (k = 0.90; R 2 = 0.91; P < 0.001; Fig. 3a) . Examination of the slope indicates that estimated bite force scaled with positive allometry relative to cranial size (b [bootstrap 95% CI] = 2.19 [2.01, 2.36]; P < 0.001). In contrast, we did not find a significant relationship between allometryfree cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force (R = 0.42; P = 0.285; Fig. 3b ). Examination of individual clades also revealed the same trend: strong positive relationships between cranial size and estimated bite force (P < 0.004; Fig. S2 ) but no significant relationship between allometry-free cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force (P > 0.154; Fig. S2 ).

The best supporting model for cranial size was the BMM model (AICw > 0.99; Table 1 ), indicating that different dietary ecologies may have influenced the evolutionary rates of cranial size but not selection towards particular trait optima. We therefore compared evolutionary rates between dietary groups under a Brownian motion model using the geomorph function compare.evol.rates (Adams, 2014b) and found that the evolutionary rates are not significantly different from each other (all P > 0.05). In contrast, the best supporting model for allometry-free cranial shape was the OUM model (AICw > 0.99; Table 1 ), indicating that different dietary ecologies influenced the evolution of distinct cranial shapes. Lastly, the best supporting model for size-corrected estimated bite force was the single peak OU model (AICw = 0.99; Table 1 ), suggesting that different dietary ecologies did not influence the evolution of relative bite forces.
body_text.section: Influence of dietary ecology on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: Phylogenetic ANOVAs and phylogenetic Procrustes ANO-VAs revealed consistent results across dietary groups. We did not find significant differences in cranial size (sum of squares (SS) = 3.666; mean squares (MS) = 0.917; adjusted R 2 = 0.391; F 4,62 = 8.713; P = 0.258) and size-corrected estimated bite forces (SS = 8.340; MS = 2.085; adjusted R 2 = 0.296; F 4,62 = 3.246; P = 0.693) between dietary groups but found significant differences in allometry-free cranial shape between dietary groups (SS = 0.003; MS = 0.001; R 2 = 0.088; F 4,62 = 1.482; P < 0.001). Post hoc pairwise permutation tests further revealed that the cranial shapes of all dietary groups with the exception of mesocarnivores were significantly different from one another (Table 2) . Furthermore, the canonical variate analysis (CVA) with the Jackknife cross-validation procedure was able to distinguish cranial shapes between all dietary groups, with an average of 71.64% correct classification across all groups (Table 3 ; Fig. 4 ). CV 1 (78.1%) separates aquatic carnivores from other musteloids, and CV 2 (15.3%) separates herbivores and hypocarnivores from all other diets (hypercarnivorous, mesocarnivorous and aquatic carnivorous). Mesocarnivorous musteloids exhibit crania that most closely resemble the mean cranial shape (Fig. 5b) . Compared to the mean cranial shape, hypercarnivorous musteloids exhibit a relatively more elongate basicranium ( Fig. 5a ) and hypocarnivorous musteloids exhibit a relatively more elongate rostrum and slightly rounder braincase (Fig 5c) . Aquatic carnivorous musteloids exhibit relatively increased mastoid breadth, flatter faces and more anterior insertion of the zygomatic arch ( Fig. 5d ), whereas herbivorous musteloids exhibit relatively increased zygomatic breadth but decreased mastoid breadth as well as a rounder braincase (Fig. 5e ).
body_text.section: Influence of dietary ecology on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: Size, but not shape, predicts musteloid estimated bite force

Size is a fundamentally important trait that influences many aspects of organismal form, performance and ecology (Schmidt-Nielsen, 1984) . Musteloids range across two and a half orders of magnitude in size from the 250 g least weasel (Mustela nivalis) to the 32 kg sea otter (Enhydra lutris; Macdonald et al., 2018); therefore, size alone alludes to the clade's remarkable Hypercarnivore Herbivore Aquatic carnivore Hypocarnivore Mesocarnivore Fig. 3 Phylogenetic generalized least squares regression between (a) cranial size and bite force and (b) allometryfree cranial shape and size-corrected bite force. Circles, hypercarnivores; triangles, mesocarnivores; squares, hypocarnivores; upside down triangles, aquatic carnivores; diamonds, herbivores. In addition to, and sometimes highly interrelated to size, differential skull proportions have also been shown to influence bite force (Herrel et al., 2005; Nogueira et al., 2009; Dollion et al., 2016) . In our data set, we found allometry in cranial shape with respect to cranial size (Fig. 2) . A recent body of work has suggested that, among closely related mammals, larger taxa exhibit relatively longer rostrums, whereas smaller taxa exhibit paedomorphic characteristics such as proportionally shorter rostrums and larger braincases (Cardini & Polly, 2013; Cardini et al., 2015; Tamagnini et al., 2017) . This pattern, termed cranial evolutionary allometry (CREA), has been uncovered in African antelopes, squirrels, fruit bats, mongooses, felids and kangaroos (Cardini & Polly, 2013; Cardini et al., 2015; Tamagnini et al., 2017) Numbers are Holm-Bonferroni-corrected P-values. Significant differences between diets are bolded. faster jaw closure during prey capture that tends to result in a decrease in relative bite force (Preuschoft & Witzel, 2005; Santana, 2015) . Our results in musteloids, however, show that relative rostrum length does not increase with increases in cranial size and therefore does not follow CREA. Rather, larger musteloids exhibit the opposite pattern: relatively wider crania with increases in cranial size via broadening of the zygomatic arches and vaulting of the braincase (Fig. 2) . Broader zygomatic arches provide additional attachment sites for the temporalis and masseter jaw adductor muscles that, in turn, facilitate increases in bite force. Although we found shape differences that suggest differences in biting ability, we did not find a significant relationship between allometry-free cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force in musteloids (Fig. 3b ). This suggests that these shape differences are not contributing much towards estimated bite force variation across musteloids, which is surprising considering that measurements of size-corrected variables (e.g. relative zygomatic breadth, relative mastoid breadth, relative head height) as well as mechanical advantage of jaw closing are viewed as strong correlates of bite force and often utilized as proxies for biting ability in mammals and many different vertebrate clades (Radinsky, 1981; Herrel et al., 2002; Westneat, 2004; Friscia et al., 2007; Collar et al., 2014) . These single variable metrics have led researchers to hypothesize that mustelids, particularly the smaller weasels and polecats, exhibit relatively larger bite forces compared to other carnivorans (Radinsky, 1981; Friscia et al., 2007) . We acknowledge, however, that the lack of relationship between relative bite force and cranial shape is primarily driven by mustelids given their much larger sample size of species. Although there appears to be a relationship between relative bite force and cranial shape within Mephitidae and Procyonidae, both these clades have too few species to make any robust interpretation ( Fig. S2) . Further investigation is needed to determine whether the mismatch between cranial shape and bite force also occurs in other more speciesrich carnivoran families.

Many-to-one mapping of form to function (Alfaro et al., 2005; Wainwright et al., 2005) may explain the lack of correlation between cranial shape and sizecorrected estimated bite force in musteloids. Because of the cranium's complexity, a variety of morphological shape differences such as relatively broader zygomatic arches, shorter rostrums and longer muscle inlevers can all lead to the same performance outcome: an increase in relative biting ability. This suggests that musteloids evolved relatively larger bite forces through a variety of evolutionary shape changes rather than a single morphological shape change. Because geometric morphometric approaches quantify the shape of the entire cranium, we are unable to tease apart specific morphological traits that may increase relative bite force. Examples of many-to-one mapping of form to function are found across vertebrates (Alfaro et al., 2005; Wainwright et al., 2005; Young et al., 2007; Collar et al., 2014; Kolmann et al., 2015; Zelditch et al., 2017) , including carnivorans. For example, durophagous carnivorans feeding on hard bones and herbivorous carnivorans feeding on tough bamboo exhibit convergent cranial shapes but distinct mandibular shapes (Figueirido et al., 2013) , trends that have been observed across multiple crown and stem carnivoran clades (Van Valkenburgh, 2007) . Although these shape differences led to differences in jaw adductor efficiency (herbivores emphasized masseter efficiency and carnivores emphasized temporalis efficiency; Tseng & Flynn, 2018) , overall relative bite forces are estimated to be similar (Christiansen & Wroe, 2007) . In addition, our morphometric approach does not capture the musculature that generates bite force. Various aspects of the jaw adductor muscles such as muscle fibre length, pennation angle and muscle activation pattern are also under selection that may lead to the evolution of relatively larger bite forces. Unfortunately, very little is known about the relationship between cranial shape, jaw adductor muscle properties and biting ability between species. Lastly, other components of feeding performance may also influence skull shapes. Researchers have revealed that skull shapes can also be influenced by skull strain energy, maximum gape, skull strength, all of which can be tied to different dietary ecologies (i.e. Slater & Van Valkenburgh, 2009; Tseng, 2013; Santana, 2015; Figueirido et al., 2016) . In addition to feeding, the cranium houses multiple structures essential for other functions such as olfaction, vision, auditory and brain processing. Therefore, these functions may also have great influences on cranial shape (see below).

Dietary ecologies greatly influence the morphology and performance of species across all vertebrate clades (e.g. Verwaijen et al., 2002; Santana et al., 2012; Collar et al., 2014; Olsen, 2017) . In mammals, Price & Hopkins (2015) found that herbivores are substantially larger than any other dietary group, carnivores are usually the smallest, and omnivores are usually intermediate in body size. Subsequent studies using the skull and finer detailed dietary categories revealed that cranial size variation does not always differ between species with different dietary ecologies (Zelditch et al., 2017; Maestri et al., 2017 but see Santana & Cheung, 2016 . Similarly, in this study, we found that dietary ecology does not influence the evolution of cranial size and size-corrected estimated bite force in musteloids. Musteloid cranial sizes do not differ between dietary groups (Table 2) , and given the strong relationship between cranial size and estimated bite force (Fig. 3a) , absolute estimated bite forces do not differ between dietary groups. In contrast, our evolutionary modelling supports independent cranial shape optima for each dietary group, suggesting that dietary ecology influences the evolution of cranial shape. Furthermore, post hoc tests reveal that cranial shapes are significantly different between most dietary groups, consistent with previous work by Dumont et al. (2015) . Cranial shapes of mesocarnivores were the exception, which most closely resemble the mean musteloid cranial shape, whereas aquatic carnivores and herbivores deviated the most from mean cranial shape. Although these shape differences (relatively wider mastoid breadth in aquatic carnivores and relatively wider zygomatic breadth in herbivores) suggest aquatic carnivorous and herbivorous musteloids exhibit relatively larger estimated bite forces compared to the remaining dietary groups, we found that these cranial shape differences do not translate to differences in biting ability between dietary groups. Rather, the sizes of these different shaped skulls are what dictate the smaller bite forces. In contrast to other mammalian clades such as bats (Nogueira et al., 2009; Santana et al., 2010 Santana et al., , 2012 and rodents (Maestri et al., 2016) , we found that size-corrected estimated bite forces do not differ between dietary groups in musteloids, which further demonstrates the lack of relationship between cranial shape and estimated bite force. This pattern is consistent across other carnivorans; the majority of carnivorans with different dietary ecologies do not exhibit significant differences in relative estimated bite force with the exception of insectivores, which exhibit relatively smaller estimated bite forces (Christiansen & Wroe, 2007) .
body_text.section: Influences of dietary ecologies on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: In addition to many-to-one mapping (see above), another possible explanation for the discrepancy between cranial shape differences but not estimated bite force differences is that other nonfeeding related variables might have greater influences on cranial shape. Tseng & Flynn (2018) recently found that cranial shape in carnivorans is correlated with not only dietary ecologies but also with life history (i.e. age of sexual maturity) and mean monthly precipitation, albeit the underlying mechanism linking these nonfeeding variables with cranial shape remains unknown. Similarly, cribriform plate size and surface area in mammal crania are strongly correlated with the number of functional olfactory receptor genes (Bird et al., 2018) , suggesting that olfaction can greatly influence cranial shape as well. The aquatic environment may also influence cranial shape, leading to relatively more streamline skulls for more efficient locomotion in water. Together, these findings highlight the need to investigate the functional relationships between cranial shape and nonfeeding sensory-ecological variables and the potential feedback that these functions may have on the covariation between cranial shape and dietary ecology (Tseng & Flynn, 2018) .
body_text.section: Influences of dietary ecologies on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: Overall, our results indicate that musteloids across different dietary ecologies exhibit different cranial shapes but do not need to converge towards particular cranial sizes and estimated bite forces to specialize on particular diets. Rather, we postulate that different diets can be obtained through specialization of other aspects of the body and behaviours that may facilitate access to different prey. Musteloid body shapes and limbs are morphologically diverse and tied to various locomotor ecologies (Schutz & Guralnick, 2007; Fabre et al., 2015; Botton Divet, 2018; Law et al. in review) , thus enabling musteloids to exploit a variety of environments more diverse than any other carnivoran clade. Therefore, specialized body plans and limbs associated with different locomotory lifestyles may facilitate different dietary ecologies by enabling access to prey items found in these different habitats. For example, within hypercarnivorous musteloids, martens (Martes spp.) and fishers (Pekania pennanti) exhibit gracile, elongate forelimbs adapted to climb and chase prey in trees (Schutz & Guralnick, 2007; Fabre et al., 2015) , whereas semi-fossorial American badgers (Taxidea taxus) and honey badgers (Mellivora capensis) exhibit short, robust forelimbs adapted to dig for subterranean prey (Schutz & Guralnick, 2007; Fabre et al., 2015; Botton Divet, 2018) . Musteline weasels and polecats (Mustela spp.), on the other hand, exhibit small, elongate body plans with relatively shorter limbs that allow them to chase rodents in crevices and underground burrows (Law et al. in review) . In addition to morphological adaptations, some musteloids also exhibit feeding behaviours that may alleviate morphological and functional constraints. For example, frugivorous procyonids such as kinkajous (Potos flavus) preferentially target riper fruit that happen to be less mechanically challenging to process than unripe fruit (Kays, 1999) . One of the more innovative feeding behaviours is tool use, which durophagous sea otters (E. lutris) perform to break open hard-shelled marine invertebrates (Riedman & Estes, 1990; Fujii et al., 2017) . Despite several cranial adaptations to facilitate durophagy [short, blunt skulls, taller and wider mandibular rami, bunodont dentition, fracture-resistant dental enamel, and positively allometric bite forces (Riley, 1985; Constantino et al., 2011; Ziscovici et al., 2014; Law et al., 2016 Law et al., , 2017 ], sea otters have relatively lower bite forces for their cranial size compared to what is predicted by the allometric slope of all musteloids (Fig. 3) . Therefore, it is tempting to postulate that the evolution of tool use behaviour precluded the need to evolve relative larger bite forces in this durophagous species. Integration of cranial, axial and appendicular morphologies with behaviour will elucidate additional insights into the evolution of dietary ecologies and other ecological factors.
body_text.section: Influences of dietary ecologies on cranial morphology and estimated bite force

body_text.text: An important caveat to our interpretation is that bite forces estimated using the dry skull method have yet to be validated with empirical bite force measurements from live musteloids. Bite forces are generated from many other components other than skull morphology including fibre length, muscles mass, orientation, pennation angle and activation pattern of the different jaw adductor muscles (Herrel et al., 1997; Davis et al., 2010; Santana et al., 2010; Law et al., 2016) . Therefore, these empirical data are essential to determine the accuracy of our bite force estimations. Unfortunately, direct measurements of bite forces are difficult to obtain from mammals due to lack of motivated bites or pathogenic risks. The few studies that have examined the accuracy of the dry skull method found inconsistent relationships between in vivo bite forces measured in live animals and estimated bite force from the same individuals using the dry skull method; the dry skull method slightly underestimates in vivo measurements in Virginia opossums (D. virginiana) and domestic dogs (Thomason, 1991; Ellis et al., 2008) but provides reasonably accurate estimation of bite force in New World leaf-nosed bats (family Phyllostomidae), albeit by underestimating temporalis forces and overestimating masseter-pterygoid forces (Davis et al., 2010) . However, even in New World leaf-nosed bats, there is considerable unexplained variation (R 2 = 0.613) between actual and estimated bite forces (Davis et al., 2010) . Because actual and estimated bite forces scale with size (van der Meij & Bout, 2004; Christiansen & Wroe, 2007; Erickson et al., 2013; Maestri et al., 2016; Santana & Miller, 2016) , both measurements are expected to correlate with one another regardless of how well the dry skull method actually estimates true bite force. Therefore, a regression between actual and estimated bite forces may not truly depict the accuracy of the dry skull method because of the effects of size. Although any unexplained variation from this scenario could potentially be attributed to size-free cranial morphology (i.e. cranial shape), uncertainty associated with this unexplained variation also could potentially mask the true relationship between actual bite force and cranial shape. Thus, bite forces estimated from the dry skull method can potentially influence our results, particularly our finding that there is no relationship between cranial shape and size-corrected bite force. Unfortunately, these potential effects are not yet known without the availability of in vivo measurements that are needed to validate the dry skull method. These data will be valuable in future investigations between actual bite force and cranial shape.

In this study, we used geometric morphometric approaches and a phylogenetic comparative framework to examine relationships between cranial shape, estimated bite force and dietary ecology in 67 species of musteloid mammals. We found cranial size variation to be the most dominant factor influencing estimated bite force variation in musteloids. Surprisingly, we found no relationship between allometry-free cranial shape and size-corrected estimated bite force, a pattern that may be explained by many-to-one mapping of form to function (Alfaro et al., 2005; Wainwright et al., 2005) . The cranium is complex, and a variety of morphological shape differences such as relatively broader zygomatic arches, shorter rostrums and longer muscle in-levers may have all contributed to similar relative biting performance outcomes across musteloid evolution. We, furthermore, found that dietary ecologies influenced cranial shape evolution but influenced neither cranial size nor sizecorrected estimated bite force evolution. That musteloids with different diets exhibit different cranial shapes but not estimated bite force suggests nonfeeding variables may be greater influences on the evolution of cranial morphology. Additionally, axial and appendicular adaptations influencing novel feeding behaviours such as tool use may also play a greater role in facilitating different dietary ecologies between species, thus highlighting the need for the integration of form and function between cranial, axial and appendicular components with different behaviours.
